# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Here is the Julia function that solves the problem:

```julia
function wrap_string(s::AbstractString, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(s, " ")
    result = ""
    line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(line * " " * word) > text_width
            result *= "\n"
            line = ""
        end
        line *= " " * word
    end
    return result * line
end
```
This function works by splitting the input string into words, then iterating over these words. For each word, it checks if adding this word to the current line would exceed the maximum text width. If so, it starts a new line. It then adds the word to the current line and continues until all words have been processed. Finally, it returns the resulting string with lines separated by newline characters.

Here is an example of how you can use this function:

```julia
s = "This is a test string that will be wrapped."
println(wrap_string(s))
```
In this case, the output would be:

```julia
"This is a 
test string 
that will be 
wrapped."
```
